bibl.title: Report: The Effect of Variation of Level of Impounded Water on the Control of Anopheles Production, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]

div1.p: Carter describes the effect of impounded water level variation on the control of Anopheles breeding, reviewing work done by himself and others in North Carolina, South Carolina, and Alabama.

div1.head: Report: The Effect of Variation of Level of Impounded Water on the Control of Anopheles Production, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
The Effect of Variation of Level of Impounded Water on the Control
of Anopheles Production.
H. R. Carter.

The problem of the effect of impounded water upon the incidence of
malaria was formulated in the fall of 1913, about ten years ago, and the
first work in its investigation was undertaken the next year at Blewetts
Falls, N. C. on the Pee Dee river.

The original plan for this investigation, which was purposed to in-
clude a determination of the methods for the control of this incidence
space
to, an extent at least, of the evaluation of the effect of the methods re-
commended for this purpose, was expected to require not less than five
years' or rather seasons' investigations, We thought that the evaluation of the methods for
control of malaria above alluded to might well require three or four years
longer time.

The problem was a large as well as an important one as on it, to
some extent, depended whether the water power in the malarial sections of
the U. S. could be developed economically or whether the damage which its
developement would cause to health would be so great and so unavoidable
that this developement would not be economically possible or at least greatly lessen
its value

It was purposed that the research on the ponds as normally made and
that of the methods to control the production of Anopheles thereby should
go hand in hand as soon as we had enough knowledge of the first to warrant
institution of the second.

Only three seasons (1914-15-16) were available for this research
before the War stopped us: some little data was collected incidentally on
this subject during the War--very little. Griffitts and myself, however,
made one survey in 1919 and I sometimes by myself orsometimes with others (Fisher and Bold-
ridge) have done some surveying within the last three years. Dr. Fricks
Fricks
-2-
this year has also formally taken up this problem again & I presume will fin-
ish it,

It was determined during the surveys of 1914-15 that, except where
floating-islands:; log rafts etc. existed. Anopheles production in these large
ponds occurred only about their edges and, indeed, far the greater propor-
tion occurred on their edges, even in those like Parr Shoals and Stevens
Creek where rafts and floating islands were abundant.

Naturally means of control of production in the ponds were practi-
cally two:--wave action, which drowned the larvae and fish which ate
them. Of course there were cases where predatory insects assisted the
fish, but as compared with them these insects were of very minor sanitary
importance.

All large ponds that we came across, by the third year at any rate,
were fairly well stocked with top minnows. In many derived of you those which those had existed in
pools covered by the pond, in others they had been artificially introduced.
Nevertheless, even in ponds, like Parr Shoals, where Gambusia were abund-
ant there was frequently large production of Anopheles on account of the
protection furnished the larvae along shore by the drift and floatage
which naturally accumulated along the shorethere, and especially in the bights
and bays of the shore-line.

Taking into consideration then the two means for the natural con-
trol of production on the ponds it was easily seen
1/ That we could do nothing to increase the efficiency of wave ac-
tion save to draw out a few obstructing log rafts and heavy drift. This
was a question of topography.
2/ That our best, and almost only, chance for control lay in get-
ting a clean waters edge for our pond so that the larvae, having no pro-
tection against the fish would be destroyed by them.

Beyond the preparation of the flowage area before the buildingfilling of
the ponddamstet, for which we had formulated specifications, it is very obvi-
ous that this edge cannot economically be kept clean of floatage and
and

drift by mechanical means. This was indeed attempted at Blewetts FallsParris Shoals S.C.
a large body of men being employed all of one spring and summer in rakingt
the edges of the pond. Of course it did some good, but it had been
cheaper to buy and abandon for settlement all the land within the dis-
tance of flight of the pond than to have continued it indefinitely and,
naturally, it would have to be continued indefinitely and the banks raked
at very short intervals. This was a small pond: Lock No. 17, Black
Warrior, was estimated (LePrince and myself) from the plans submitted by
the U. S. Engineers, to have over 132 miles of edge. Hand raking was ob-
viously not to be considered for this ponddistance.

As early as 1915 a plan for clearing these edges, economically feas-
ible, was formulated and recommended to the Alabama Power Co. at Lock #12
of the Coosa. This pond had been filled some two years previously, and be-
ing accredited--to an extent justly--with having caused a very large a-
mount of malaria in its environment--was the defendant in a number of suits
totaling to a large amount. The plaint made against the pond: that it had been high
in the spring of the year and, as it had been lowered from the use of the
water it left all its edges covered with “offensive mud bared to the hot
sun and thus had produced a miasma which caused the malaria.”

There was little doubt of the increase of malaria in some places
after the pond was filled. To obviate this alleged cause of the malaria the Company then
put in a telephone line from near the headwaters dam to get connection with the power plant so they
might be forewarned of the arrivalcoming or the passing of high water. Whenever this
was threatened they opened their weir and lowered the pond in advance so
that there would be no rise beyond what they counted their normal level.
They put in elsewherealso a supplemental steam plant and whenever the use of
the water threatened to leave bare these “malaria producing mud flats”
they drew on their water power the least possible, supplementing it by
steam, thus doing all that was possible to keep the pond at constant lev-
el and incidentally, by Keeping the drift at the banks afloat, removed any
any
-4-
possibility of fish control and thus increased the production of Anopheles
from their pond as much as was humanly possible--and at very considerable
expense to themselves.

It was recommended to them for the present to let the pond fluctu-
ate as much as possible: to catch every rise, so as to bring the floatage
high up on the bank and tothen lower the pond by use or otherwise as much as
was possible so as to strand itsthis floatage on the banks with the larvae that
it sheltered, as the pond went down.

The fullgeneral recommendations, for a pond already in existence, as agreed
to by LePrince: Griffitts and myself, were formulated as follows:
1/ To hold the level of the pond as high as possible during the
season when A. quad. were not producing, i. e. the late fall: winter and
as long as we could into the next season. This would kill the land vege-
tation up to this level. The drift and floatage accumulated during this
period would also be collected along this the margin of the water, extending a
certain distance therefrom.
2/ Just prior, and as close as possible, to the first flight of A.
quad. from pond water: lower the pond as much as is reasonably possible.
This would leave all--or nearly all--floatage and drift then floating against the banks
stranded on the on banks when the pond went down: the aim being (a) to kill
the larvae in this floatage and (b) to leave a clean water's edge around the
pond.
3/ During the summer to catch and hold every rise of the river
for a few daysas long as possible (but less than two weeks) and then run the pond down to clean
edges again.

Obviously, it might take more than one season of high level to kill
all the land vegetation: two, or at most three, would, however, do so.

Similarly, it might not be economically feasible to lower the pond
enough to land all the trash floating around its edges at the beginning of the
Anopheles production season. We have found, however, that a- the greater
greater
-5-
proportion of this floatage could be thus landed--all we cannot say, ex-
cept where the banks are steep. Indeed, contratry to our first judgement,
mosquito production on the gently sloping banks was more easily controlled
than on the steep ones, as even a small fall of the level would, on the
former, land a large area of floatage while, on the steep banks a much
less one would be landed for the same & all of the pond.

One can easily see-knowing the biology of Anopheles--how this
plan ought to work for control of their breedingproduction: As the water fell the
larvae would be left stranded on the land: as it rose--especially if it
rose rapidly--the masses of floatage would be, to an extent, broken up
and the Anopheles larvae exposed to fish, and, for the great majority of
the time, the water's edge would be clean and free from floatage:--in
the worst possible condition for mosquito production. It is not neces-
sary to tell you field men, however, that we have never been satisfied
with a method, however good it might be in theory, that had not been
checked up in the field. We indeed saw a little of this around Talladega
Springs, but not enough to be called a check of the method and it is
this that I now wish to present to you:

In the spring of 1921, on my return from Peru, I was asked by the
Superintendant of a large hydro-electric plant what measures could be then
taken with his pond at to prevent it being a source of malaria. His state-
ment was that at that time (in May, I believe) that the pond was level
with the spillway. I advised him to hold it up as high as he could--to
that level if possible--to about the middleend of June, or even a little
later--and then lower it (whether by use or wastage) 2 ft. or even 3 ft.
and thereafter hold the rises and lower the level after them, as per the
previous recommendation given above,

I visited this place on Aug. 10th. and lived with two other men
in a tent on its bank in the upper reaches (about 50 ft. from the water). I
I
-6-
stayed at this place for six days:--the working days of one week. During
that time only one mosquito was found in the tent. This was, unfortunate-
ly mashed and its genus could not be determined. A considerable por-
tion of the pond--its upper reaches--was examined during these six days:
The edges were practically bare, the floatage being landed well above the
water and, except where creeks and streams entered and on a log-raft, Ano-
pheles larvae were not found. There was, in places a slight collection of
drift along the edges, evidently come since the pond had been lowered
(about July 10th.) but this was so slight that it seemed to furnish in-
sufficient protection to larvae, at any rate none were found in it. Top-
minnows were fairly abundant, especially near the mouths of streams and
in bights: nor were Imagoes were not found in the houses that thewere examined more or
less adjacent to the pond & a fair number were examined.

Griffitts and myself had been over this pond in 1919 somewhat later
in the year, but with far less pains and taking less time than I put on it
in 1921. We had found the edges far from clean and breeding in several
places: also in some houses a fair number of A. quad. All the places
which had been found breeding in 1919 were examined in/21--and examined pains-
takingly--and in no single one was breeding found. In mouths of streams
there was sometimesoccasionally found a fair amount of floatage: sometimes due to the
banks being steep at this place so that it was not landed: sometimes,
doubtless, from being washed down the streams since the pond had been
lowered. Where Spirogyria algae was found in this floatage we were apt
to find larvae. A few of these developed into quads. and hence were
doubtless from pond breeding, the majority were punctipennis and pro-
bably washed down from the stream.

This same pond was visited again this year, in early August. It
had been lowered intentionally about 16 ft. Two days careful examination by
three people (Dr. Boldridge: Mr. Gage and myself) resulted in finding
five larvae just below the mouths of the creeks which, in running water,
water
-7-
were breeding--scantily, indeed, but many fold more than the pond was.
The banks were generally free from drift and floatage: in some bights,
however, this was found, especially near the mouths of streams. None of
of the larvae taken were large enough to justify attempts to develope them.

This examination on, on account of my becoming sick, was not com-
pleted:--I had expected to give at least six more days to it, but Le-
Prince examined this pond in what seemed to be the most favorable places
for mosquito production for some days and Mr. Gage also (the latter both
before and after my imperfect examination). (They will tell you what they
found. (If they are not here, I will tell you that their results were
negative- up to the time of my leaving Oct 8/)
Omit

Another large pond (in S. C. was examined by Dr. Boldridge and my-
self with some pains in 1921 (I was there about 3 weeks). The pond was
some 3 ft. or 4 ft. below the spillway at this time and the edges (ex-
cept in the back-water of creeks) were clean. There was no breeding of
sanitary importance found in the pond, or even in the back-water of the
creeks, which were alive with Gambusia. Portions of the same pond were
examined by myself for six days in the summer of 1922 with the same re-
sult--it being then some 2 ft. below level & with clean banks,

Naturally, these observations are not nearly so extensive as
should be made, yet they are a beginning and I think the findings from
them are sufficient to, tentatively, justify the recommendations made in
1915 and to show that the change of level of a pond lessens its production
of Anopheles and can be so handled as well-nigh to prevent it. This, of
course, applies only to production on the banks of ponds--not to log-
rafts and floating islands, which would be but little, or not at all, affected by it.
And, unlike hand-cleaning of the banks, this method of getting clean water-
edges is always feasible and probably in general economically practicable.

Obviously, the lowering of a pond from its early summer high-water
high-water
-8-
mark, if done simply by the use of the water, costs nothing and cleans
the banks fairly efficiently.

If the use of the water does not accomplish this and the pond is
cleared by wastage through the weir this is done at considerable cost to
the Power Company, yet it may be well worth doing as a sanitary measure.
It was so done--intentionally I mean--at the pond of which I first gave
the history and I cannot but think that the production of Anopheles pre-
vented thereby justified the expenditure. Indeed, from the little I saw
and from LePrince's verbal reports I think it is fair to say that at this
time a unit area of the pond was producing fewer Anopheles than a unit
of its land environment: it was lessening not increasing proda Anopheles production

This method awaits and calls for further observation and devel-
opement. It is “up to” you Field Men.
